     257             : 
     258             : /* Resolve types of formal argument lists.  These have to be done early so that
     259             :    the formal argument lists of module procedures can be copied to the
     260             :    containing module before the individual procedures are resolved
     261             :    individually.  We also resolve argument lists of procedures in interface
     262             :    blocks because they are self-contained scoping units.
     263             : 
     264             :    Since a dummy argument cannot be a non-dummy procedure, the only
     265             :    resort left for untyped names are the IMPLICIT types.  */

    1109             : 
    1110             : 
    1111             : /* Resolve contained function types.  Because contained functions can call one
    1112             :    another, they have to be worked out before any of the contained procedures
    1113             :    can be resolved.
    1114             : 
    1115             :    The good news is that if a function doesn't already have a type, the only
    1116             :    way it can get one is through an IMPLICIT type or a RESULT variable, because
    1117             :    by definition contained functions are contained namespace they're contained
    1118             :    in, not in a sibling or parent namespace.  */
    1119             : 
    1120             : static void
    1121      138053 : resolve_contained_functions (gfc_namespace *ns)
    1122             : {
    1123      138053 :   gfc_namespace *child;
    1124      138053 :   gfc_entry_list *el;
    1125             : 
    1126      138053 :   resolve_formal_arglists (ns);
    1127             : 
    1128      157969 :   for (child = ns->contained; child; child = child->sibling)
    1129             :     {
    1130             :       /* Resolve alternate entry points first.  */
    1131       19916 :       resolve_entries (child);
    1132             : 
    1133             :       /* Then check function return types.  */
    1134       19916 :       resolve_contained_fntype (child->proc_name, child);
    1135       20321 :       for (el = child->entries; el; el = el->next)
    1136         405 :         resolve_contained_fntype (el->sym, child);
    1137             :     }
    1138      138053 : }

    2301             : /* This function does the checking of references to global procedures
    2302             :    as defined in sections 18.1 and 14.1, respectively, of the Fortran
    2303             :    77 and 95 standards.  It checks for a gsymbol for the name, making
    2304             :    one if it does not already exist.  If it already exists, then the
    2305             :    reference being resolved must correspond to the type of gsymbol.
    2306             :    Otherwise, the new symbol is equipped with the attributes of the
    2307             :    reference.  The corresponding code that is called in creating
    2308             :    global entities is parse.c.
    2309             :

    3718             : /* Convert a logical operator to the corresponding bitwise intrinsic call.
    3719             :    For example A .AND. B becomes IAND(A, B).  */
    3720             : static gfc_expr *
    3721         666 : logical_to_bitwise (gfc_expr *e)
    3722             : {
    3723         666 :   gfc_expr *tmp, *op1, *op2;

    3731         666 :   op2 = e->value.op.op2;

    3733         666 :   switch (e->value.op.op)
    3734             :     {
    3735             :     case INTRINSIC_NOT:
    3736             :       isym = GFC_ISYM_NOT;

    3738         126 :     case INTRINSIC_AND:
    3739         126 :       isym = GFC_ISYM_IAND;
    3740         126 :       break;
    3741         126 :     case INTRINSIC_OR:
    3742         126 :       isym = GFC_ISYM_IOR;
    3743         126 :       break;
    3744         270 :     case INTRINSIC_NEQV:
    3745         270 :       isym = GFC_ISYM_IEOR;
    3746         270 :       break;

    3748             :       /* "Bitwise eqv" is just the complement of NEQV === IEOR.
    3749             :          Change the old expression to NEQV, which will get replaced by IEOR,
    3750             :          and wrap it in NOT.  */

    4697             : 
    4698             : /* Given an expression that contains array references, update those array
    4699             :    references to point to the right array specifications.  While this is
    4700             :    filled in during matching, this information is difficult to save and load
    4701             :    in a module, so we take care of it here.
    4702             : 
    4703             :    The idea here is that the original array reference comes from the
    4704             :    base symbol.  We traverse the list of reference structures, setting
    4705             :    the stored reference to references.  Component references can
    4706             :    provide an additional array specification.  */
    4707             : 
    4708             : static void
    4709         770 : find_array_spec (gfc_expr *e)

    4717             :   else
    4718         758 :     as = e->symtree->n.sym->as;
    4719             :

    4722             :       {
    4723         784 :       case REF_ARRAY:
    4724         784 :         if (as == NULL)
    4725           0 :           gfc_internal_error ("find_array_spec(): Missing spec");
    4726             :

    4728         784 :         as = NULL;
    4729         784 :         break;

    7986             :           /* Default initialization via MOLD (non-polymorphic).  */
    7987          20 :           gfc_expr *rhs = gfc_default_initializer (&code->expr3->ts);
    7988          20 :           if (rhs != NULL)
    7989             :             {
    7990           7 :               gfc_resolve_expr (rhs);
    7991           7 :               gfc_free_expr (code->expr3);

    7993             :             }
    7994             :         }

    7997             :

    8011             : 
    8012             : 
    8013             : /************ SELECT CASE resolution subroutines ************/
    8014             : 
    8015             : /* Callback function for our mergesort variant.  Determines interval
    8016             :    overlaps for CASEs. Return <0 if op1 < op2, 0 for overlap, >0 for
    8017             :    op1 > op2.  Assumes we're not dealing with the default case.
    8018             :    We have op1 = (:L), (K:L) or (K:) and op2 = (:N), (M:N) or (M:).
    8019             :    There are nine situations to check.  */
    8020             : 
    8021             : static int
    8022        1563 : compare_cases (const gfc_case *op1, const gfc_case *op2)
    8023             : {
    8024        1563 :   int retval;
    8025             : 
    8026        1563 :   if (op1->low == NULL) /* op1 = (:L)  */
    8027             :     {
    8028             :       /* op2 = (:N), so overlap.  */
    8029          52 :       retval = 0;
    8030             :       /* op2 = (M:) or (M:N),  L < M  */
    8031          52 :       if (op2->low != NULL
    8032          52 :           && gfc_compare_expr (op1->high, op2->low, INTRINSIC_LT) < 0)
    8033             :         retval = -1;
    8034             :     }
    8035        1511 :   else if (op1->high == NULL) /* op1 = (K:)  */
    8036             :     {
    8037             :       /* op2 = (M:), so overlap.  */
    8038          10 :       retval = 0;
    8039             :       /* op2 = (:N) or (M:N), K > N  */
    8040          10 :       if (op2->high != NULL
    8041          10 :           && gfc_compare_expr (op1->low, op2->high, INTRINSIC_GT) > 0)
    8042             :         retval = 1;
    8043             :     }
    8044             :   else /* op1 = (K:L)  */
    8045             :     {
    8046        1501 :       if (op2->low == NULL)       /* op2 = (:N), K > N  */
    8047          18 :         retval = (gfc_compare_expr (op1->low, op2->high, INTRINSIC_GT) > 0)
    8048          18 :                  ? 1 : 0;
    8049        1483 :       else if (op2->high == NULL) /* op2 = (M:), L < M  */
    8050          10 :         retval = (gfc_compare_expr (op1->high, op2->low, INTRINSIC_LT) < 0)
    8051          10 :                  ? -1 : 0;
    8052             :       else                      /* op2 = (M:N)  */
    8053             :         {
    8054        1473 :           retval =  0;
    8055             :           /* L < M  */
    8056        1473 :           if (gfc_compare_expr (op1->high, op2->low, INTRINSIC_LT) < 0)
    8057             :             retval =  -1;
    8058             :           /* K > N  */
    8059         328 :           else if (gfc_compare_expr (op1->low, op2->high, INTRINSIC_GT) > 0)
    8060         326 :             retval =  1;
    8061             :         }
    8062             :     }
    8063             : 
    8064        1563 :   return retval;
    8065             : }
    8066             : 
    8067             : 
    8068             : /* Merge-sort a double linked case list, detecting overlap in the
    8069             :    process.  LIST is the head of the double linked case list before it
    8070             :    is sorted.  Returns the head of the sorted list if we don't see any
    8071             :    overlap, or NULL otherwise.  */
    8072             : 
    8073             : static gfc_case *
    8074         596 : check_case_overlap (gfc_case *list)
    8075             : {
    8076         596 :   gfc_case *p, *q, *e, *tail;
    8077         596 :   int insize, nmerges, psize, qsize, cmp, overlap_seen;
    8078             : 
    8079             :   /* If the passed list was empty, return immediately.  */
    8080         596 :   if (!list)
    8081             :     return NULL;
    8082             : 
    8083             :   overlap_seen = 0;
    8084             :   insize = 1;
    8085             : 
    8086             :   /* Loop unconditionally.  The only exit from this loop is a return
    8087             :      statement, when we've finished sorting the case list.  */
    8088         909 :   for (;;)
    8089             :     {
    8090         909 :       p = list;
    8091         909 :       list = NULL;
    8092         909 :       tail = NULL;
    8093             : 
    8094             :       /* Count the number of merges we do in this pass.  */
    8095         909 :       nmerges = 0;
    8096             : 
    8097             :       /* Loop while there exists a merge to be done.  */
    8098        2316 :       while (p)
    8099             :         {
    8100        1407 :           int i;
    8101             : 
    8102             :           /* Count this merge.  */
    8103        1407 :           nmerges++;
    8104             : 
    8105             :           /* Cut the list in two pieces by stepping INSIZE places
    8106             :              forward in the list, starting from P.  */
    8107        1407 :           psize = 0;
    8108        1407 :           q = p;
    8109        3066 :           for (i = 0; i < insize; i++)
    8110             :             {
    8111        2163 :               psize++;
    8112        2163 :               q = q->right;
    8113        2163 :               if (!q)
    8114             :                 break;
    8115             :             }
    8116             :           qsize = insize;
    8117             : 
    8118             :           /* Now we have two lists.  Merge them!  */
    8119        4779 :           while (psize > 0 || (qsize > 0 && q != NULL))
    8120             :             {
    8121             :               /* See from which the next case to merge comes from.  */
    8122        3372 :               if (psize == 0)
    8123             :                 {
    8124             :                   /* P is empty so the next case must come from Q.  */
    8125         855 :                   e = q;
    8126         855 :                   q = q->right;
    8127         855 :                   qsize--;
    8128             :                 }
    8129        2517 :               else if (qsize == 0 || q == NULL)
    8130             :                 {
    8131             :                   /* Q is empty.  */
    8132         954 :                   e = p;
    8133         954 :                   p = p->right;
    8134         954 :                   psize--;
    8135             :                 }
    8136             :               else
    8137             :                 {
    8138        1563 :                   cmp = compare_cases (p, q);
    8139        1563 :                   if (cmp < 0)
    8140             :                     {
    8141             :                       /* The whole case range for P is less than the
    8142             :                          one for Q.  */
    8143        1205 :                       e = p;
    8144        1205 :                       p = p->right;
    8145        1205 :                       psize--;
    8146             :                     }
    8147         358 :                   else if (cmp > 0)
    8148             :                     {
    8149             :                       /* The whole case range for Q is greater than
    8150             :                          the case range for P.  */
    8151         354 :                       e = q;
    8152         354 :                       q = q->right;
    8153         354 :                       qsize--;
    8154             :                     }
    8155             :                   else
    8156             :                     {
    8157             :                       /* The cases overlap, or they are the same
    8158             :                          element in the list.  Either way, we must
    8159             :                          issue an error and get the next case from P.  */
    8160             :                       /* FIXME: Sort P and Q by line number.  */
    8161           4 :                       gfc_error ("CASE label at %L overlaps with CASE "
    8162             :                                  "label at %L", &p->where, &q->where);
    8163           4 :                       overlap_seen = 1;
    8164           4 :                       e = p;
    8165           4 :                       p = p->right;
    8166           4 :                       psize--;
    8167             :                     }
    8168             :                 }
    8169             : 
    8170             :                 /* Add the next element to the merged list.  */
    8171        3372 :               if (tail)
    8172        2463 :                 tail->right = e;
    8173             :               else
    8174             :                 list = e;
    8175        3372 :               e->left = tail;
    8176        3372 :               tail = e;
    8177             :             }
    8178             : 
    8179             :           /* P has now stepped INSIZE places along, and so has Q.  So
    8180             :              they're the same.  */
    8181             :           p = q;
    8182             :         }
    8183         909 :       tail->right = NULL;
    8184             : 
    8185             :       /* If we have done only one merge or none at all, we've
    8186             :          finished sorting the cases.  */
    8187         909 :       if (nmerges <= 1)
    8188             :         {
    8189         596 :           if (!overlap_seen)
    8190             :             return list;
    8191             :           else
    8192           4 :             return NULL;
    8193             :         }
    8194             : 
    8195             :       /* Otherwise repeat, merging lists twice the size.  */
    8196         313 :       insize *= 2;
    8197         313 :     }
    8198             : }
    8199             : 
    8200             : 
    8201             : /* Check to see if an expression is suitable for use in a CASE statement.
    8202             :    Makes sure that all case expressions are scalar constants of the same
    8203             :    type.  Return false if anything is wrong.  */
    8204             : 
    8205             : static bool
    8206        3075 : validate_case_label_expr (gfc_expr *e, gfc_expr *case_expr)
    8207             : {
    8208        3075 :   if (e == NULL) return true;
    8209             : 
    8210        2984 :   if (e->ts.type != case_expr->ts.type)
    8211             :     {
    8212           0 :       gfc_error ("Expression in CASE statement at %L must be of type %s",
    8213             :                  &e->where, gfc_basic_typename (case_expr->ts.type));
    8214           0 :       return false;
    8215             :     }
    8216             : 
    8217             :   /* C805 (R808) For a given case-construct, each case-value shall be of
    8218             :      the same type as case-expr.  For character type, length differences
    8219             :      are allowed, but the kind type parameters shall be the same.  */
    8220             : 
    8221        2984 :   if (case_expr->ts.type == BT_CHARACTER && e->ts.kind != case_expr->ts.kind)
    8222             :     {
    8223           4 :       gfc_error ("Expression in CASE statement at %L must be of kind %d",
    8224             :                  &e->where, case_expr->ts.kind);
    8225           4 :       return false;
    8226             :     }
    8227             : 
    8228             :   /* Convert the case value kind to that of case expression kind,
    8229             :      if needed */
    8230             : 
    8231        2980 :   if (e->ts.kind != case_expr->ts.kind)
    8232          12 :     gfc_convert_type_warn (e, &case_expr->ts, 2, 0);
    8233             : 
    8234        2980 :   if (e->rank != 0)
    8235             :     {
    8236           0 :       gfc_error ("Expression in CASE statement at %L must be scalar",
    8237             :                  &e->where);
    8238           0 :       return false;
    8239             :     }
    8240             : 
    8241             :   return true;
    8242             : }
    8243             : 
    8244             : 
    8245             : /* Given a completely parsed select statement, we:
    8246             : 
    8247             :      - Validate all expressions and code within the SELECT.
    8248             :      - Make sure that the selection expression is not of the wrong type.
    8249             :      - Make sure that no case ranges overlap.
    8250             :      - Eliminate unreachable cases and unreachable code resulting from
    8251             :        removing case labels.
    8252             : 
    8253             :    The standard does allow unreachable cases, e.g. CASE (5:3).  But
    8254             :    they are a hassle for code generation, and to prevent that, we just
    8255             :    cut them out here.  This is not necessary for overlapping cases
    8256             :    because they are illegal and we never even try to generate code.
    8257             : 
    8258             :    We have the additional caveat that a SELECT construct could have
    8259             :    been a computed GOTO in the source code. Fortunately we can fairly
    8260             :    easily work around that here: The case_expr for a "real" SELECT CASE
    8261             :    is in code->expr1, but for a computed GOTO it is in code->expr2. All
    8262             :    we have to do is make sure that the case_expr is a scalar integer
    8263             :    expression.  */
    8264             : 
    8265             : static void
    8266         621 : resolve_select (gfc_code *code, bool select_type)
    8267             : {
    8268         621 :   gfc_code *body;
    8269         621 :   gfc_expr *case_expr;
    8270         621 :   gfc_case *cp, *default_case, *tail, *head;
    8271         621 :   int seen_unreachable;
    8272         621 :   int seen_logical;
    8273         621 :   int ncases;
    8274         621 :   bt type;
    8275         621 :   bool t;
    8276             : 
    8277         621 :   if (code->expr1 == NULL)
    8278             :     {
    8279             :       /* This was actually a computed GOTO statement.  */
    8280           3 :       case_expr = code->expr2;
    8281           3 :       if (case_expr->ts.type != BT_INTEGER|| case_expr->rank != 0)
    8282           2 :         gfc_error ("Selection expression in computed GOTO statement "
    8283             :                    "at %L must be a scalar integer expression",
    8284             :                    &case_expr->where);
    8285             : 
    8286             :       /* Further checking is not necessary because this SELECT was built
    8287             :          by the compiler, so it should always be OK.  Just move the
    8288             :          case_expr from expr2 to expr so that we can handle computed
    8289             :          GOTOs as normal SELECTs from here on.  */
    8290           3 :       code->expr1 = code->expr2;
    8291           3 :       code->expr2 = NULL;
    8292           3 :       return;
    8293             :     }
    8294             : 
    8295         618 :   case_expr = code->expr1;
    8296         618 :   type = case_expr->ts.type;
    8297             : 
    8298             :   /* F08:C830.  */

    8302             :                  &case_expr->where, gfc_typename (&case_expr->ts));

    8341             : 
    8342             :   /* PR 19168 has a long discussion concerning a mismatch of the kinds

    8459             :             {
    8460             :               /* If the case range can be matched, it can also overlap with
    8461             :                  other cases.  To make sure it does not, we put it in a
    8462             :                  double linked list here.  We sort that with a merge sort
    8463             :                  later on to detect any overlapping cases.  */

    8465             :                 {
    8466         596 :                   head = tail = cp;
    8467         596 :                   head->right = head->left = NULL;
    8468             :                 }
    8469             :               else
    8470             :                 {
    8471         903 :                   tail->right = cp;

    8473         903 :                   tail = tail->right;
    8474         903 :                   tail->right = NULL;

    8476             :             }
    8477             :         }
    8478             : 
    8479             :       /* It there was a failure in the previous case label, give up
    8480             :          for this case label list.  Continue with the next block.  */
    8481        1663 :       if (!t)
    8482             :         continue;
    8483             : 
    8484             :       /* See if any case labels that are unreachable have been seen.
    8485             :          If so, we eliminate them.  This is a bit of a kludge because
    8486             :          the case lists for a single case statement (label) is a
    8487             :          single forward linked lists.  */
    8488        1658 :       if (seen_unreachable)
    8489             :       {
    8490             :         /* Advance until the first case in the list is reachable.  */
    8491          34 :         while (body->ext.block.case_list != NULL

    9281             : 
    9282             : /* Resolve a transfer statement. This is making sure that:
    9283             :    -- a derived type being transferred has only non-pointer components
    9284             :    -- a derived type being transferred doesn't have private components, unless
    9285             :       it's being transferred from the module where the type was defined
    9286             :    -- we're not trying to transfer a whole assumed size array.  */
    9287             :

    9653             : /* Given a branch to a label, see if the branch is conforming.

    9657       83155 : resolve_branch (gfc_st_label *label, gfc_code *code)
    9658             : {
    9659       83155 :   code_stack *stack;

    9823             :          statement in where-body-construct of a WHERE construct */

    9864             : /* Resolve assignment in FORALL construct.

    9867             : 
    9868             : static void
    9869        1831 : gfc_resolve_assign_in_forall (gfc_code *code, int nvar, gfc_expr **var_expr)

    9871        1831 :   int n;
    9872             :

    9874             :     {

    9878             : 
    9879             :       /* Check whether the assignment target is one of the FORALL index
    9880             :          variable.  */

   10025             : /* Given a FORALL construct, first resolve the FORALL iterator, then call

   10027             :

   10030             : {

   10575             : /* Makes a temporary variable expression based on the characteristics of
   10576             :    a given variable expression.  */
   10577             : 
   10578             : static gfc_expr*
   10579         242 : get_temp_from_expr (gfc_expr *e, gfc_namespace *ns)
   10580             : {
   10581         242 :   static int serial = 0;
   10582         242 :   char name[GFC_MAX_SYMBOL_LEN];

   10585         242 :   gfc_array_ref *aref;
   10586         242 :   gfc_ref *ref;
   10587             : 
   10588         242 :   sprintf (name, GFC_PREFIX("DA%d"), serial++);
   10589         242 :   gfc_get_sym_tree (name, ns, &tmp, false);
   10590         242 :   gfc_add_type (tmp->n.sym, &e->ts, NULL);
   10591             : 
   10592         242 :   as = NULL;

   10594         242 :   aref = NULL;
   10595             :

   10659             : 
   10660             : 
   10661             : /* Add one line of code to the code chain, making sure that 'head' and
   10662             :    'tail' are appropriately updated.  */
   10663             : 
   10664             : static void
   10665         497 : add_code_to_chain (gfc_code **this_code, gfc_code **head, gfc_code **tail)
   10666             : {
   10667         497 :   gcc_assert (this_code);
   10668         497 :   if (*head == NULL)
   10669         221 :     *head = *tail = *this_code;
   10670             :   else
   10671         276 :     *tail = gfc_append_code (*tail, *this_code);
   10672         497 :   *this_code = NULL;
   10673         497 : }
   10674             : 
   10675             : 
   10676             : /* Counts the potential number of part array references that would
   10677             :    result from resolution of typebound defined assignments.  */
   10678             : 
   10679             : static int
   10680         199 : nonscalar_typebound_assign (gfc_symbol *derived, int depth)
   10681             : {
   10682         199 :   gfc_component *c;
   10683         199 :   int c_depth = 0, t_depth;
   10684             : 
   10685         477 :   for (c= derived->components; c; c = c->next)
   10686             :     {
   10687         278 :       if ((!gfc_bt_struct (c->ts.type)
   10688             :             || c->attr.pointer
   10689         211 :             || c->attr.allocatable
   10690         211 :             || c->attr.proc_pointer_comp
   10691             :             || c->attr.class_pointer
   10692         211 :             || c->attr.proc_pointer)
   10693          67 :           && !c->attr.defined_assign_comp)
   10694             :         continue;
   10695             : 
   10696         211 :       if (c->as && c_depth == 0)
   10697          30 :         c_depth = 1;
   10698             : 
   10699         211 :       if (c->ts.u.derived->attr.defined_assign_comp)
   10700         110 :         t_depth = nonscalar_typebound_assign (c->ts.u.derived,
   10701             :                                               c->as ? 1 : 0);
   10702             :       else
   10703             :         t_depth = 0;
   10704             : 
   10705         211 :       c_depth = t_depth > c_depth ? t_depth : c_depth;
   10706             :     }
   10707         199 :   return depth + c_depth;
   10708             : }
   10709             : 
   10710             : 
   10711             : /* Implement 7.2.1.3 of the F08 standard:
   10712             :    "An intrinsic assignment where the variable is of derived type is
   10713             :    performed as if each component of the variable were assigned from the
   10714             :    corresponding component of expr using pointer assignment (7.2.2) for
   10715             :    each pointer component, defined assignment for each nonpointer
   10716             :    nonallocatable component of a type that has a type-bound defined
   10717             :    assignment consistent with the component, intrinsic assignment for
   10718             :    each other nonpointer nonallocatable component, ..."
   10719             : 
   10720             :    The pointer assignments are taken care of by the intrinsic
   10721             :    assignment of the structure itself.  This function recursively adds
   10722             :    defined assignments where required.  The recursion is accomplished
   10723             :    by calling gfc_resolve_code.
   10724             : 
   10725             :    When the lhs in a defined assignment has intent INOUT, we need a
   10726             :    temporary for the lhs.  In pseudo-code:
   10727             : 
   10728             :    ! Only call function lhs once.
   10729             :       if (lhs is not a constant or an variable)
   10730             :           temp_x = expr2
   10731             :           expr2 => temp_x
   10732             :    ! Do the intrinsic assignment
   10733             :       expr1 = expr2
   10734             :    ! Now do the defined assignments
   10735             :       do over components with typebound defined assignment [%cmp]
   10736             :         #if one component's assignment procedure is INOUT
   10737             :           t1 = expr1
   10738             :           #if expr2 non-variable
   10739             :             temp_x = expr2
   10740             :             expr2 => temp_x
   10741             :           # endif
   10742             :           expr1 = expr2
   10743             :           # for each cmp
   10744             :             t1%cmp {defined=} expr2%cmp
   10745             :             expr1%cmp = t1%cmp
   10746             :         #else
   10747             :           expr1 = expr2
   10748             : 
   10749             :         # for each cmp
   10750             :           expr1%cmp {defined=} expr2%cmp
   10751             :         #endif
   10752             :    */
   10753             : 
   10754             : /* The temporary assignments have to be put on top of the additional
   10755             :    code to avoid the result being changed by the intrinsic assignment.
   10756             :    */
   10757             : static int component_assignment_level = 0;
   10758             : static gfc_code *tmp_head = NULL, *tmp_tail = NULL;
   10759             : 
   10760             : static void
   10761         144 : generate_component_assignments (gfc_code **code, gfc_namespace *ns)
   10762             : {
   10763         144 :   gfc_component *comp1, *comp2;
   10764         144 :   gfc_code *this_code = NULL, *head = NULL, *tail = NULL;
   10765         144 :   gfc_expr *t1;
   10766         144 :   int error_count, depth;
   10767             : 
   10768         144 :   gfc_get_errors (NULL, &error_count);
   10769             : 
   10770             :   /* Filter out continuing processing after an error.  */
   10771         288 :   if (error_count
   10772         144 :       || (*code)->expr1->ts.type != BT_DERIVED
   10773         144 :       || (*code)->expr2->ts.type != BT_DERIVED)
   10774           6 :     return;
   10775             : 
   10776             :   /* TODO: Handle more than one part array reference in assignments.  */
   10777         144 :   depth = nonscalar_typebound_assign ((*code)->expr1->ts.u.derived,
   10778         144 :                                       (*code)->expr1->rank ? 1 : 0);
   10779         144 :   if (depth > 1)
   10780             :     {
   10781           6 :       gfc_warning (0, "TODO: type-bound defined assignment(s) at %L not "
   10782             :                    "done because multiple part array references would "
   10783             :                    "occur in intermediate expressions.", &(*code)->loc);
   10784           6 :       return;
   10785             :     }
   10786             : 
   10787         138 :   component_assignment_level++;
   10788             : 
   10789             :   /* Create a temporary so that functions get called only once.  */
   10790         276 :   if ((*code)->expr2->expr_type != EXPR_VARIABLE
   10791         138 :       && (*code)->expr2->expr_type != EXPR_CONSTANT)
   10792             :     {
   10793          50 :       gfc_expr *tmp_expr;
   10794             : 
   10795             :       /* Assign the rhs to the temporary.  */
   10796          50 :       tmp_expr = get_temp_from_expr ((*code)->expr1, ns);
   10797         150 :       this_code = build_assignment (EXEC_ASSIGN,
   10798             :                                     tmp_expr, (*code)->expr2,
   10799          50 :                                     NULL, NULL, (*code)->loc);
   10800             :       /* Add the code and substitute the rhs expression.  */
   10801          50 :       add_code_to_chain (&this_code, &tmp_head, &tmp_tail);
   10802          50 :       gfc_free_expr ((*code)->expr2);
   10803          50 :       (*code)->expr2 = tmp_expr;
   10804             :     }
   10805             : 
   10806             :   /* Do the intrinsic assignment.  This is not needed if the lhs is one
   10807             :      of the temporaries generated here, since the intrinsic assignment
   10808             :      to the final result already does this.  */
   10809         138 :   if ((*code)->expr1->symtree->n.sym->name[2] != '@')
   10810             :     {
   10811         138 :       this_code = build_assignment (EXEC_ASSIGN,
   10812             :                                     (*code)->expr1, (*code)->expr2,
   10813             :                                     NULL, NULL, (*code)->loc);
   10814         138 :       add_code_to_chain (&this_code, &head, &tail);
   10815             :     }
   10816             : 
   10817         138 :   comp1 = (*code)->expr1->ts.u.derived->components;
   10818         138 :   comp2 = (*code)->expr2->ts.u.derived->components;
   10819             : 
   10820         138 :   t1 = NULL;
   10821         342 :   for (; comp1; comp1 = comp1->next, comp2 = comp2->next)

   11004             : /* F2008: Pointer function assignments are of the form:
   11005             :         ptr_fcn (args) = expr

   12762             :

   13022             : 
   13023             : /* Worker function for resolving a generic procedure binding; this is used to
   13024             :    resolve GENERIC as well as user and intrinsic OPERATOR typebound procedures.
   13025             : 
   13026             :    The difference between those cases is finding possible inherited bindings
   13027             :    that are overridden, as one has to look for them in tb_sym_root,

   13604             : static bool
   13605        1113 : ensure_not_abstract (gfc_symbol* sub, gfc_symbol* ancestor)
   13606             : {
   13607             :   /* The algorithm used here is to recursively travel up the ancestry of sub
   13608             :      and for each ancestor-type, check all bindings.  If any of them is
   13609             :      DEFERRED, look it up starting from sub and see if the found (overriding)
   13610             :      binding is not DEFERRED.
   13611             :      This is not the most efficient way to do this, but it should be ok and is
   13612             :      clearer than something sophisticated.  */
   13613             : 
   13614        1190 :   gcc_assert (ancestor && !sub->attr.abstract);
   13615             : 
   13616        1190 :   if (!ancestor->attr.abstract)
   13617             :     return true;
   13618             : 
   13619             :   /* Walk bindings of this ancestor.  */
   13620        1189 :   if (ancestor->f2k_derived)
   13621             :     {
   13622        1189 :       bool t;
   13623        1189 :       t = ensure_not_abstract_walker (sub, ancestor->f2k_derived->tb_sym_root);
   13624        1189 :       if (!t)
   13625             :         return false;
   13626             :     }
   13627             : 
   13628             :   /* Find next ancestor type and recurse on it.  */
   13629        1186 :   ancestor = gfc_get_derived_super_type (ancestor);
   13630        1186 :   if (ancestor)
   13631             :     return ensure_not_abstract (sub, ancestor);
   13632             : 
   13633             :   return true;
   13634             : }

   16067             :     }
   16068             :   return true;
   16069             : }
   16070             : 
   16071             : 
   16072             : /* Resolve equivalence object.
   16073             :    An EQUIVALENCE object shall not be a dummy argument, a pointer, a target,
   16074             :    an allocatable array, an object of nonsequence derived type, an object of
   16075             :    sequence derived type containing a pointer at any level of component
   16076             :    selection, an automatic object, a function name, an entry name, a result
   16077             :    name, a named constant, a structure component, or a subobject of any of
   16078             :    the preceding objects.  A substring shall not have length zero.  A
   16079             :    derived type shall not have components with default initialization nor
   16080             :    shall two objects of an equivalence group be initialized.
   16081             :    Either all or none of the objects shall have an protected attribute.
   16082             :    The simple constraints are done in symbol.c(check_conflict) and the rest
   16083             :    are implemented here.  */
   16084             : 
   16085             : static void
   16086        1551 : resolve_equivalence (gfc_equiv *eq)
   16087             : {
   16088        1551 :   gfc_symbol *sym;
   16089        1551 :   gfc_symbol *first_sym;

   16091        1551 :   gfc_ref *r;
   16092        1551 :   locus *last_where = NULL;
   16093        1551 :   seq_type eq_type, last_eq_type;
   16094        1551 :   gfc_typespec *last_ts;

   16655             : 
   16656             : /* This function is called after a complete program unit has been compiled.
   16657             :    Its purpose is to examine all of the expressions associated with a program
   16658             :    unit, assign types to all intermediate expressions, make sure that all
   16659             :    assignments are to compatible types and figure out which names refer to
   16660             :    which functions or subroutines.  */

LCOV profile is generated on x86_64 machine using following configure options: configure --disable-bootstrap --enable-coverage=opt --enable-languages=c,c++,fortran,go,jit,lto --enable-host-shared. GCC test suite is run with the built compiler.
